heisig_chinese_memo: Both a meter and a yard are about one normal arm length.  But these three arms are 100 Chinese inches!
heisig_constituent: length, stick, tucked under the arm
heisig_story: The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large (Frame 112).
Keyword_KANJIDIC: length, 10feet, measure, Mr., Ms., height, stature, all (one has), only, that's all, merely

koohiiStory1: Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.
koohiiStory2: This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare "length" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldnÂ´t show "it" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic:
The height radical and the height kanji are the same!
That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of ten feet. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: When you think of height think of our huge farmhand friend, Jourm (ã˜ã‚‡ã†). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's ten feet tall.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Jourm really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, but ten feet is too high for you to reach.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Both a meter and a yard are about one normal arm length.  But these three arms are 100 Chinese inches!
humanum_full_description_en:
" Zhang " is a commonly used character in Qin and Han unearthed documents. The original meaning is a unit of measurement, and ten feet is zhang. Warring States Qin Jian " Joe " wording sometimes falsely become like a " branch ", even after the Wei simplify pen to distinguish between " support " its current shape and almost no other regular script (ANCIENT). "Said Wen": "Ten Chi also. Cong holds ten." Duan Yucai's note: "Ten Chi also. Cong holds ten. Husband said: "Eight inches in Zhou system are feet, and ten feet are feet. Eight feet, hence the husband.â€ Then he stretched out his arms and looked for the zhang of Zhou. So Cong held ten.â€ The classics use its original meaning, such as "Zuo Zhuanâ€§ Ai Gongyuan": "Zhang inside, wide zhang, high times ." Another example is "Huainanzi Tiantian": "Ten inches is a ruler, and ten feet is a meter." The original meaning of the script is also used in the script, such as "Mawangdui. Line 296 of the Book of Political Strategists in the Warring States Period: "The city of ten thousand feet, the guard of a million, the food of five years."

" Zhang " is also used for measurement, such as "Zuo Zhuanâ€§ The Nine Years of Xianggong": "Tour Zhangcheng." Du pre-notes: "Zhang, Du Ye." This is also used in scripts and silk scripts, such as "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Jianâ€§ Law Questions and Answers" Jane 6: "Fu Zhang, six feet and seven inches high.

" Zhang " is also used to address male elders, such as Lao Zhang, Yue Zhang, etc. "Da Dai Li Jiâ€§ Ben Ming": "Zhang Zhe, Chang Ye." Tang and Song poetry sees this usage, such as Du Fu in the Tang Dynasty "Presented to Li Bazhang Judge": "When I was Zhang Yingte, Zong Zhi Shen Yao." "Five Zongzhi": "Duan Yan Chunqiu high, so it is based on Zhang Shi."

" Zhang " can mean the abbreviation of husband, such as uncle, sister-in-law, etc. For example, "Tai Ping Guang Ji" Volume 3 86 cited "Ming Xiang Ji-Xie Hong Chang's Wife": "Although I don't know the face, it seems to be the voice of my uncle Shen Jiguang. Xu Wenyun, the voice seems to be Shen Zhang, why has no head Hugu and uncle in the south are both named Zhang Ye."

" Zhang " can also be used as a " stick " to express support and leaning. "Yu Pianâ€§ Zhang Bu": "Zhang, Fu Ye." "Warring States Policyâ€§Qi Ce Six": "Sitting and weaving è’‰, standing up and inserting." "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slipsâ€§ Japanese Book A Type" Jian 33 back -1: "The heart is a stick (stick), the ghost comes and (strikes) it, fearing death."
humanum_short_description_en: The explanatory form of "Shuowen" is "Congyouzhishi", and its original meaning is the unit of measurement.

Heisig constituents: length, stick, tucked under the arm
Heisig: The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large (Frame 112).
Chinese: Both a meter and a yard are about one normal arm length. But these three arms are 100 Chinese inches!
koohii1: Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.
koohii2: This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare "length" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldnÂ´t show "it" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.
Meaning: 100 chinese inches
Story: Both a meter and a yard are about one normal arm length. But these three arms are 100 Chinese inches!
Kind: both

" Zhang" is a commonly used character in Qin and Han unearthed documents. The original meaning is a unit of measurement, and ten feet is zhang. Warring States Qin Jian " Joe" wording sometimes falsely become like a " branch", even after the Wei simplify pen to distinguish between " support" its current shape and almost no other regular script (ANCIENT). "Said Wen": "Ten Chi also. Cong holds ten." Duan Yucai's note: "Ten Chi also. Cong holds ten. Husband said: "Eight inches in Zhou system are feet, and ten feet are feet. Eight feet, hence the husband.â€ Then he stretched out his arms and looked for the zhang of Zhou. So Cong held ten.â€ The classics use its original meaning, such as "Zuo Zhuanâ€§ Ai Gongyuan": "Zhang inside, wide zhang, high times ." Another example is "Huainanzi Tiantian": "Ten inches is a ruler, and ten feet is a meter." The original meaning of the script is also used in the script, such as "Mawangdui. Line 296 of the Book of Political Strategists in the Warring States Period: "The city of ten thousand feet, the guard of a million, the food of five years." " Zhang" is also used for measurement, such as "Zuo Zhuanâ€§ The Nine Years of Xianggong": "Tour Zhangcheng." Du pre-notes: "Zhang, Du Ye." This is also used in scripts and silk scripts, such as "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Jianâ€§ Law Questions and Answers" Jane 6: "Fu Zhang, six feet and seven inches high. " Zhang" is also used to address male elders, such as Lao Zhang, Yue Zhang, etc. "Da Dai Li Jiâ€§ Ben Ming": "Zhang Zhe, Chang Ye." Tang and Song poetry sees this usage, such as Du Fu in the Tang Dynasty "Presented to Li Bazhang Judge": "When I was Zhang Yingte, Zong Zhi Shen Yao." "Five Zongzhi": "Duan Yan Chunqiu high, so it is based on Zhang Shi." " Zhang" can mean the abbreviation of husband, such as uncle, sister-in-law, etc. For example, "Tai Ping Guang Ji" Volume 3 86 cited "Ming Xiang Ji-Xie Hong Chang's Wife": "Although I don't know the face, it seems to be the voice of my uncle Shen Jiguang. Xu Wenyun, the voice seems to be Shen Zhang, why has no head Hugu and uncle in the south are both named Zhang Ye." " Zhang" can also be used as a " stick" to express support and leaning. "Yu Pianâ€§ Zhang Bu": "Zhang, Fu Ye." "Warring States Policyâ€§Qi Ce Six": "Sitting and weaving è’‰, standing up and inserting." "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slipsâ€§ Japanese Book A Type" Jian 33 back -1: "The heart is a stick (stick), the ghost comes and (strikes) it, fearing death."

Radicals: ä¸ˆ  (height)
Meaning Mnemonic
The height radical and the height kanji are the same!
That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of ten feet. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall.
If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
Reading Mnemonic
When you think of height think of our huge farmhand friend, Jourm (ã˜ã‚‡ã†). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's ten feet tall.
Jourm really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, but ten feet is too high for you to reach.
